It is the number in the middle. I remember by thinking of small, medium/median, large. If there are an odd number of items in your set, it’s literally the one in the middle. If there are an even number of items, you take the two in the middle, add them, then divide by two. For example, “1, 2, 3, 4, 5” has a median of 3. “1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6” has a median of 3+4/2=3.5

Don't worry, I gotchu>  So think of a CEO who earns 1,000,000 doillars a year while the Janitor earns 10,000 dollars a year.  If we think of a company with 1,000 employees, wouldn't the "average" salary be spiked up? To make this simpler, let's scale it down.  CEO earns 1,000 Manager earns 500 (1) Senior earns 300 (2) Employee earns 100 (4) Interns earns 50 (5)  If we arrange them in ascending order, with the parenthesis meaning how many of them are, let's try.  50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 100, 100, 100, 100, 300, 300, 500, 10,000  Find the data point at the center which would be 100, 100 is the median(middle).  But if we do the mean(average), 10,750/13, would be 826.923076923, which is not what you're looking for.  Applications of median is useful especially if you want data points like the CEOs not to affect the "average" you're looking for.

@UnknownUser049 no, there are just multiple modes. There is no limit on how many modes for a set, they are distinct items that appear the most in the set the same number of times.

Based on the definition of mode: "A set of numbers with two modes is bimodal, a set of numbers with three modes is trimodal, and any set of numbers with more than one mode is multimodal. [...] The mode is not defined when there are no repeats in a data set."
